Next up is Leah followed by Megan.
Good afternoon.
My name is Leah and I am the Washington transportation policy manager I climate solution.

We are in strong support of Seattle city light's transportation Electrification strategic investment plan and the ordinance that would grant city light the authority to offer transportation Electrocution program.
We are excited these past out of committee and I would like to see the same at full council this afternoon.
The transportation sector is responsible for the largest share of Seattle's greenhouse gas emission and air pollution.
Is the Washington environmental health disparities map shows, this pollution is also not equal.
It is urgent both for the climate and for our health that we power our transit, freight and other vehicles with city lights 100% clean electricity.
Without utility support we will not be able to rapidly Electrify at the rate necessary to meet Seattle's climate goals.

Please grant city lights authority to legally do this work so we can move forward with a more detailed implementation plan including program development based on extensive community outreach, particularly with in our mental justice communities.
Any and all vehicles on the road need to be cleaned.
This is a step in that direction.
It is also a benefit to all city like customers since it will put more pressure on rates not to mention the positive health impacts.
We cannot delay climate action any longer.
More time we take to cut emissions the harder it will be due, thank you for your comment, I urge your support.
Thank you for calling in.
Next up is Megan followed by Karen.
Hello, I am Megan speaking on CB 119877.
Emergency legislation that strayed from its original mission.
First I'd like to say I strongly support extending virtual design review meetings during Covid.
Sdci reports the virtual system has been a success and running since August.
It has been well received.

For these reasons I asked the Council to reject the bill provisions that undercut virtual meetings by allowing development that elected debris in internal review to remain out of the public eye through the end of the year.
This involves dozens of large great projects that posted public notices telling neighbors it was temporary.
And the project would return to virtual design as soon as they were available.
In addition, without explanation the bill sponsor has dropped an amendment to reduce the length of the meeting without reason it will last for half a year beyond the Covid emergency declaration.
Special interest loophole in the extended Timeline have turned the emergency bill into an effort to change design review policy.
Something the Council rejected as it wasn't the original intent.

Before passing this bill, please, number one, limit extending its provisions to three months, and two, require they provide a list of additional projects that would now be allowed to remain in Apr along with reasons.
And require each of these to reissue a public notice to neighbors.
Council members, your constituents rely on you to balance the influence of special interest.
Please stand by your original pledge.
Don't use Covid as a reason to deny neighbors and local design review board a public voice.
Thank you.
Thank you for calling in.
Next up is Karen followed by Diane.
Hello my name is Karen.
I am a downtown Seattle resident.
I'm speaking in regards to CB 119877.
This will allow almost 4 dozen market rate development project to continue in administrative design review will be on the end of the Mayor's Covid emergency order.
Since this temporary provision was put in place, virtual meetings have expanded and are able to handle these projects.
Citizens no longer need to be excluded from participation and assessing element plans which will affect the livability of our city for years to come.
Unlike developers, I cannot afford to make large contributions your reelection campaign.
All I can do is urge you to remember you were elected to save the serve the best interest of the people of Seattle.
Shutting us out of design review process makes me wonder where your allegiance lies.
Please do not pass this bill.
Thank you.
Next up is Diane followed by Annabelle.
My name is Diane glover.
I am a Pediatric infectious disease doctor and today I am representing the Washington physicians for social responsibility.
We are a group of health professionals advocating for policies that protect our health and climate.
Thank you for the opportunity to come and comment strong support of resolution 31971 and CB 119895.
We are excited our Seattle city light is pursuing the transportation Electrification plan.
The transportation sector as you know is responsible for the largest share of Seattle's greenhouse gas emission and toxic air pollution.
Lower income communities and communities of color bear the brunt of this pollution.
For example, diesel particulate pollution contributes to a reduction in life expectancy by 13 years.
For those folks living in the Duwamish valley as compared to other cleaner parts of the city.
It is urgent that we instead power our transit, freight and other vehicles for 100% clean electricity rather than fossil fuel.
A new study released by the American lung Association found that Seattle could save $1 billion in health costs through a transition to electric vehicles.
Is a Pediatric infectious disease specialist I care for very vulnerable, sick, premature babies.
Many with chronic lung disease due to the Prematurity.
These babies are extremely vulnerable to toxic air pollution with risks of asthma, pneumonia, Stentorian failure and need for hospitalization.
I also care for kids with asthma, pneumonia and Immunologic problems.
Please help my patients and our community have a better chance of thriving in a cleaner, safer air quality environment.
Thank you.
Next up is Annabelle the Lord by Megan.
Good afternoon.
My name is Annabelle, a policy associate at the energy coalition, an alliance of over 100 member organizations United around clean and affordable energy.
Our work focuses on the intersection of transportation and utility sector eight Northwest utilities at various levels on the design of their transportation Electrification plans and programs.
I am here in support of the transportation Electrification strategic infection plan, I urge you to adopt the resolution and to pass Council bill 119895.
There's an obligation to reliably serve customers.
And as electric vehicle adoption of all vehicle classes continues to accelerate, it is imperative that Seattle city light practice supporting the efficient integration of this.

Practice planning is imperative to ensure direct and indirect benefits for all customers especially for front-line communities and low-income households who are disproportionately impacted by air pollution and higher transportation energy burdens.
Its priorities, its priority investment areas were developed with meaningful input from Stakeholders and community members and align with community needs.

Includes several commitments by Seattle city light's including the continuing inclusive collaboration to integrate components into new program offerings to avoid or reduce the need for transmission and distribution upgrade.
This is essential to support greater access to affordable energy for Seattle city light customers.
And to continue the Participatory process that will help evaluate equitable access to Te and more.
These are essential components of Te planning and more.
They will guide along with Stakeholders and environmental justice communities.
Thank you.
I urge your support.
Thank you for calling in.

We believe the scheduled times and resolution, December 1 through January 5 could be used in part for this purpose.
This resolution currently provides approximately five minutes for appeals.
That is not enough to resent each appeal.

In light of the requirement that each case is subject to a separate appeal to city council objectors request a briefing schedule and separate hearing for each of our cases within a reasonable amount of time for example 30 minutes for argument.
Extraordinary circumstances exist here which allows for this.
Are appeals consist of thousands of pages of testimony over 14 days of hearing.
There is no record yet prepared.
We also believe a Prehearing conference can make the process more efficient.
For example by hearing appeals for related properties together.
Like the four seasons hotel which has three parcels.
That should be the same day.
Harbor steps apartment towers should also be considered together.
It would be more efficient to pull Hyatt properties together.

We closed our cases in April, six months ago.
And a lot has happened since then.
Covid-19, pier 58 closure.
Ongoing protests in downtown.
These events impact property valuation and special benefits.
We request the opportunity to drive the relative changes to our appeals.
That is all.

An ordinance relating to the city light Department; amending section 21.49.090 of the Seattle municipal code to clarify the Department's discretion to allow additional services on a parcel as it deems necessary to provide adequate service to customers.

Seattle city light, one of the two utility Enterprises we are fortunate to own and operate has five items on today's agenda.
These were reviewed during the extra meeting we had the transportation utilities Committee for 25.
We were able to vote on four of those five items which are committee committed unanimously.
And we as the entire city council will vote on those later today.
In addition are committee received a briefing on this item which is before us today is Council bill 19902.
The theme of all of this legislation is Electrification.
Electrification to benefit our environment.
As we know, Seattle city light divides clean hydroelectric power so the more we can use it instead of other forms of energy the better.
If this Council bill 119 902 updates the city of Seattle one site, one service policy.
So charging stations and infrastructure for electric vehicles can be more easily installed even after property already has service.
We want to make it easier for people to use zero emission vehicles and this legislation helps with that.
Thank you.

Council bill 119903.

An ordinance relating to city employment, commonly referred to as the third quarter 2020 employment ordinance; returning positions to the civil service system; and establishing a new title and corresponding rate of pay; all by a 2/3 vote of the city council.
Thank you.
I will move to pass Council bill in 19903.
Is 32nd?
Second.
Thank you so much.
A sponsor of the bill, I will address it and then open the floor to any comments or questions.
Colleagues, as I mentioned this morning this legislation does two things.
First it returns eight positions to the civil service system and second it creates a new job title in the legislative Department.
Central staff has not identified any issues or concerns with the transmitted legislation.
With regard to the eight positions, several Department of human resources director has determined the work performed by these eight positions no longer be the criteria for civil service exemption.
He recommends returning the positions to civil service.

October 2 memo drafted by analyst the table of the positions by way of summary these positions are in various departments putting the office of planning and community development, Seattle office for civil rights, education and early learning, finance, arts and culture, Department of transportation and the community Commission.
Of the eight positions only two at Sdot and one at Opcd are currently filled.
The remaining positions are vacant.

The impact of these positions is that they are returned to the civil service system which means the employees in these positions now or in the future will be afforded a range of additional job protection including Merit-Based hiring, Probationary periods of employment, opportunity to direct performance issues, and cause of termination rather than at will employment.
The additional rules are detailed in the October 2 memorandum.
The second component of this bill relates to the legislative Department.
This legislation ACCEPTS the director's recommendation to create a new job title of manager of legislative.

This new job title would Delineate responsibilities among professional and managerial staff the currently have the same title of strategic advisor and it creates an opportunity for career progression and succession planning within the cultural Council central staff.
In conclusion this is cause neutral.
Executive is indicated returning this to the civil service system would not increase cost because it does mean they would remain at the same pay rate after the change.
In other words the legislation changes the job protections for these positions but does not modify the existing ranges of available pay for the eight positions I described.
With regard to the new job title in the legislative Department to pay and for that is parallel to that of strategic advisor in the legislative Department.
This does not modify the pay band available for this job title creation.
Any additional cost for this job title canon will be absorbed by the legislative Department existing budget authority and would not require new appropriation of funds moving forward.
I am happy to hear any additional comments or take any questions on the bill.
Hearing no additional comments, will the clerk please call the roll on the passage of the bill?

Council bill 119877.

An ordinance relating to land use review decision and meeting procedures; temporarily modifying and suspending procedures in titles 23 and 25 of the Seattle municipal code and amending chapters 23.41, 23.49, 23.66, 23.79, 25.12, 25.16, 25.20, 25.21, 25.22, 25.24, and 25.30 of the Seattle municipal code.
The committee recommends the city council passed the amended Council bill divided report.
Thank you.
This legislation extends provisions that allow for virtual design review and landmark ward meetings to continue until the end of Covid- 19 emergency.

You will recall in April we adopted emergency legislation in response to the Covid-19 emergency which allowed projects that would originally go to design review boards to instead be considered for administrative design review which is conducted by staff.
When we passed that legislation, council made clear we expected the Department neighborhoods to start virtual design meetings of the design review and landmark sport a is possible.
Sdci Department of neighborhoods worked hard to move these complex meetings to virtual format which included the need for additional staff.
These meetings are now up and running and are going well.
This legislation allows for those virtual meetings to continue for the duration of Covid-19.
And automatically Sunsets two months after the emergency ends to allow time to ramp up in person meetings again.
Is the original legislation required, new projects except for affordable housing are now going through full design review board processes again.
Because virtual meetings have begun.
This legislation does not propose to change that.

The legislation does allow for limited number of projects that already started the administrative design review process to stay in the administrative design review process through the end of this year.
Specifically projects that can stay through December if the project has completed the early design guidance process or if Sdci cannot provide a virtual meeting before the ordinance takes effect.
Of the 67 projects opted into administrative design review through the emergency ordinance, there are currently just 15 who qualify for the end of this year.
Administrative design review still includes opportunity for public input akin to full design review even though it is not a full design review.
As I mentioned at Council briefing this morning, I did consider other to bring an amendment that would've shortened this Timeline of this legislation to six months from now.
For us to be able to consider modifications to be made or aspects of the bill working well and should be made permanent.
I am not bringing that amendment for this afternoon because it is better policy to simply extend these temporary provisions for the duration of the emergency.
Rather we will do the work between now and then to understand which of these changes are working well so that at the end of the Covid emergency we are ready to make changes for the new environment.

As well we retain the opportunity to make permanent or make modification before the Covid emergency is over on a separate track as to not Conflate this emergency integrate changes from the permanent or ongoing changes needed.
Finally, I have heard from some residents who share their concerns about the legislation and some of whom we heard in public comment today.
My staff or I have met with many repeatedly in the recent weeks and we appreciate the conversations.
It enabled us to understand concerns more in depth.
We even brought an amendment to shorten the original duration of this legislation directly respond to the issues that she raised.

It was originally proposed to be six months, the extension of this legislation would be in effect six months past the end of the Covid emergency and we have reduced that to two months past the Covid emergency.
I've heard from central staff it takes about three months for us, due to public requirements and other Land-Use code requirements for us to make needed changes.
That is why we will get working before the Covid emergency is over so when the Covid civil emergency is ended we will be ready to take the next step.
This policy does not allow new projects past design review, it ensures the process continues smoothly and safely during these extra Neri times.
This bill is an extension of the bill passed in April.
I encourage your support.
Thank you colleagues, thank you Council President.
Thank you Councilmember Strauss for that report.
Farther any additional comments on the bill?
Councilmember Mosqueda, please.
Thank you very much.
Councilmember Strauss, I want to say thank you for your leadership Stewarding us through this process.
I think it's really important.
I'm very excited to vote for this.
I understand it's a small but important measure.
I don't want to Oversell its impact or the significance because it is more of a process in nature, making sure the functions of court government can continue during this crisis.
I wasn't planning to speak but I do think it's important to clarify for the record, there is nothing this Council is doing that is trying to use Covid as an excuse to change policy.

In fact what we are doing is being responsible stewards of the public's health by making sure Sissies can continue and to do so in a way that protects the very vulnerable in our community and frankly all of us.
Covid has no bounds, it will infect people whether they are young or old, it happens to be those who are elderly and with underlying health conditions that are more susceptible to death.

So while we continue to see increases in the number of Covid cases in our city and our region, we also take pride as a Seattle times as noted, that Seattle's among the largest cities that has been slower, the slowest rate of infection among this population.
We have taken very important measures led by public health data that is intended to both slow transmission and also keep our population healthy.

As we think about who are the individuals who would more likely be in a situation to become exposed, it would be those inside a closed room for long periods of time making the opportunity for this to participate electronically is the right thing to do for public health and also recognizes that when we force people to go back to In-Person meetings, sooner than they should be, we will effectively be screening out those who have underlying health conditions and those who may be elderly because they are not going to be able to participate in an in person room.
This is a smart thing for us to do.
It is sound public health policy we are following.
It allows for our city to continue to govern in a thoughtful way that is cognizant of the public health.

So, I do take issue with any sort of accusation that this is being done for any other policy rationale other than trying to protect the public health and make sure the city government core functions can continue.

This is why Seattle is leading the nation in strong public health policies and helping to slow the spread of transmission . We cannot continue to keep up those Statistics that were reported by the Seattle times if we rush to reopen or try to get back to normal.
There is no getting back to normal.
I appreciate Councilmember Strauss's sponsor of this legislation recognizing we have to continually update our policy and practices.
We have built in time to do so.
But we must, must center policy both on public health and protecting the most mobile in our city.
That's what this policy does.
Again, it's a small procedural change to make sure we can move forward.
I thought I needed to speak up and correct the record.
Thank you Councilmember Mosqueda.
Thank you, Madam chair, I want to take time to think Councilember Strauss for navigating an issue that has been very difficult and that none of us anticipated was going to come up in 2020.
Really, changing the paradigm of how we do this essential process of community in Golan involvement in that there can be continuity technology to make it happen.

And that we can stand up a system like this and I appreciate the opportunity to collaborate with Councilmember Strauss on a couple of changes that Councilmember Strauss made in his introductory remarks on the bill regarding the Timeline post Covid that I know are important to a lot of constituents in district 7. and appreciate that was unincorporated in committee.

I know there has been a lot of concern in the community on both sides with this legislation since the spring as an opportunity to sort of Litigate the merits of design review and to try to fight that battle in the context of this basically emergency legislation.
It certainly was in the spring and it is now more of a normal ordinance.
But still collecting an emergency situation.
And I would just say that I am sure that is a conversation and discussion that will come in time.
But we need to make sure that the essential functions of government can continue in times of crisis and that they be adapted to reflect the public health situation.
As Councilmember Mosqueda said, make sure we are giving everyone the space to dissipate in these processes in a Safeway.
I do want to say, it really is due to the nature of the emergency.
I don't think anyone on this Council is thrilled that a lot of the work of the city has to be done remotely right now.
But to protect those that we love and those were vulnerable in the community, this is really an essential thing to do.
And I also want to thank Sdci for being able to stand up a pretty impressive system to do this.
Is Council members Strauss stressed, the ADR administrative design review board for market rate projects has 15 projects already invested in summer in late spring.
That will expire at the end of the year, going into 2021 we should be on and all virtual footing for these projects, except for the projects that otherwise have exemption.
I look forward to voting for this legislation today.
No one is excited that a lot of these processes that typically involve in person outreach have to be put on a virtual footing.
But it really is in the best interest of best practices in public health to do it this way.
And again, I just appreciate Sdci and Councilmember Strauss's leadership in that complicated situation and doing it quite well.
I appreciate it.
Thank you.
Thank you Councilmember Lewis.
Thank you, Council President.
Kudos to Councilmember Strauss for navigating this in the amendment to shorten the Timeframe.
The legislation seem to do a couple different things.
I definitely appreciate rationale for continuing to exempt certain affordable housing projects for both design review and administrative design review.
Most affordable housing projects receive city money and a required to do a separate community engagement process anyway.
For me it's about if we can maximize public input, community engagement, I am in favor of that.
I am glad Sdci has stood up the virtual design review process.
My concern is this bill would, those 15 projects, we get to keep the administrative design review benefit for themselves.
They are all for profit market rate projects.
I just think they should have to go back to the regular design review since they can do it virtually, safely Online and provide additional input.
Consistent with my committee vote I will be voting no on this legislation.
Thank you.
Thank you.

I just want to speak a little bit to some of the issues that have been raised about the question of whether or not the Council is sort of using the state of emergency to make changes to important policies and procedures for public input.

Given that I voted against this legislation back and I believe it was April, I want to clarify for the record, that the reason I did so in April was because we had, we were operating under a different set of rules, and of course there was different interpretations of those rules under the types of legislation that we were permitted to be acting on.
It seems like ancient history now.
But we were limited to taking action on emergency legislation for the governor and the AG.
I thought at the time a portion of this ordinance did not fit into that rubric.
That is not the case any longer.
For that reason I feel comfortable voting in support of this legislation.
Thank you.
Thank you for reminding us that legislative history, it was only in April, but you are right, it feels like 1 million years ago already.
And an excellent point that the proclamation limits exemptions related to the open public meetings act has been pretty drastically modified to allow us to consider things not related to bid anymore.
I appreciate the reminder around that . any other comments on this bill?
Councilmember Strauss, you have the last word as it appears no one else is interested in making any comments.
Thank you.

Just to also echo the words of Councilmember Herbold and Councilmember Mosqueda, that this is not a way to use the Covid emergency to make changes to legislation, there have been a number of aspects of this legislation that have done very well in community.
Virtual design is one of them.
One of the things I wanted to begin looking at is if we could make a combination of in person and virtual design review.

Because of requirements that in person design review meetings occur in and near the community and project they are reviewing, it does make it difficult to Cohabitate virtual and in person design review meetings.
Because a lot of the rooms they are held in are not set up for the technology that we need to use virtual design review.

Again, separating permanent changes from this temporary, from this extension of emergency and temporary exchanges demonstrates we are not slipping anything through using this emergency as a cover, rather we are making important process changes that protect public health and continue the direction we are heading with a number of Covid cases we have in our community.
So, I look forward to reviewing the positives and the drawbacks that this emergency and legislation has created.
And making further changes to our design review process in the future.
Thank you.

This bill and the resolution will be voting on next are the legislation that is legally required by the state before Seattle city light can provide financial incentives to switch from vehicles that burn gas and diesel to electric vehicles that can run on the Hydropower.

When you compare Seattle city light, are publicly owned and operated utility to Puget sound energy, the private For-Profit utility that SELLS electricity generated by burning natural gas in the neighboring cities, it is a very clear example of why public investment for the green NW deal are essential to address climate change.
